articles.title: This Clam Is One Of The World’s Longest-Living Animals, And It Has Troubling News About The Future - IFLScience
articles.description: This Clam Is One Of The World’s Longest-Living Animals, And It Has Troubling News About The Future  IFLScienceMassive system of rotating ocean currents in the North Atlantic is behaving strangely — and it may be reaching a tipping point  Live ScienceNew Study Shows Disruption of Ocean Currents That Stabilize the Global Climate  Inside Climate NewsClam shells sound warning of Atlantic ‘tipping point’  University of ExeterSpecies that can live 500 years offers warning of North Atlantic ‘tipping point’  The Daily Gazette
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.title: Astronomers discover ultra-luminous infrared galaxy lurking behind quasar
articles.description: An international team of astronomers has used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) to observe a well-known quasar known as the Cloverleaf. As part of the observations, they serendipitously discovered a new ultra-luminous infrared galaxy. The finding was reported September 30 in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Rare disease possibly identified in 12th century child's skeletal remains
articles.description: In the journal Childhood in the Past, Ph.D. candidate Duru Yağmur Başaran published the results of an analysis of an over 900-year-old skeleton of a child. The study revealed that a 2.5 to 3.5-year-old child had suffered from a rare disease seldom seen in archaeology.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Chemical pollutants affect wildlife and human behavior—but toxicologists are reluctant to carry out tests
articles.description: Most environmental scientists believe that chemical pollution can and is negatively affecting people and wildlife, according to my team's recent survey.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: The evolution of male mental health in television
articles.description: Shows about men still dominate our television screens. But the stories being told are starting to change, with more room for vulnerability and portrayals of male mental illness. These changes include explicit mentions of diagnostic categories and male characters with mental illnesses in the lead role.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Setting your home up for success: Small animal owner fire awareness
articles.description: Half a million pets are affected by home fires each year, with more than 40,000 of those animals losing their lives, according to the American Veterinary Medical Association.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Pointless work tasks driving employees to switch off and burn out, new research finds
articles.description: Unfair or pointless work tasks are driving more employees to mentally check out, turning to the internet to cope with stress, sleepless nights, and next-day burnout, new research shows.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: California physicist and Nobel laureate John Martinis won't quit on quantum computers
articles.description: A California physicist and Nobel laureate who laid the foundation for quantum computing isn't done working.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Siobhan Roberts
articles.title: Every Artist Has a Favorite Subject. For Some, That’s Math.
articles.description: At the annual Bridges conference, mathematical creativity was on dazzling display.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Sarah Hurtes, Jeffrey Gettleman and Emile Ducke
articles.title: Curious Reindeer and Charging Polar Bears: The Changing Wildlife at the Top of the Earth
articles.description: Climate change is transforming ecosystems in the far north. An international team of scientists has made some surprising discoveries.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: A new method to build more energy-efficient memory devices could lead to a sustainable data future
articles.description: A research team led by Kyushu University has developed a new fabrication method for energy-efficient magnetic random-access memory (MRAM) using a new material called thulium iron garnet (TmIG) that has been attracting global attention for its ability to enable high-speed, low-power information rewriting at room temperature. The team hopes their findings will lead to significant improvements in the speed and power efficiency of high-computing hardware, such as that used to power generative AI.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Freely levitating rotor spins out ultraprecise sensors for classical and quantum physics
articles.description: With a clever design, researchers have solved eddy-current damping in macroscopic levitating systems, paving the way for a wide range of sensing technologies.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Arctic seals and more than half of bird species are in trouble on latest list of threatened species
articles.description: Arctic seals and more than half of bird species are in trouble on latest list of threatened species
articles.source: Yahoo News

articles.title: Plastic pollution treaty not dead in the water: UN environment chief
articles.description: The UN's environment chief insists that a landmark global treaty tackling plastic pollution remains achievable, despite talks twice imploding without agreement, and the chair suddenly resigning this week.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Powerful earthquake off southern Philippines kills 2 people, causes damages and tsunami evacuations
articles.description: A 7.4-magnitude earthquake Friday morning off the southern Philippines killed at least two people, damaged a hospital and schools, knocked out power and prompted evacuations of coastal areas nearby due to a tsunami warning, which was later lifted.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: She saw a car-sized object above a Texas farm and found a wayward hunk of NASA equipment
articles.description: When Ann Walter looked outside her rural West Texas home, she didn't know what to make of the bulky object slowly drifting across the sky.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Catrin Einhorn
articles.title: I.U.C.N. Updates Its Red List on the Global Status of Wildlife
articles.description: Sea turtles are making a surprising comeback, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature. The news was not so good for Arctic seals.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Green turtle bounces back from brink in conservation 'win'
articles.description: Once endangered due to hunting, it is making a strong recovery thanks to global conservation efforts.
articles.source: BBC News - Science & Environment

articles.title: What Is This Prehistoric Animal With Two Heads? We Asked A Dinosaur Expert - IFLScience
articles.description: What Is This Prehistoric Animal With Two Heads? We Asked A Dinosaur Expert  IFLScience
articles.source: Google News Science GB

articles.title: Thermo Fisher Scientific Announces R&D Partnership with AstraZeneca BioVentureHub
articles.description: The PPD™ clinical research business of Thermo Fisher Scientific announce a new research and development (R&D) partnership with the AstraZeneca BioVentureHub in Gothenburg, Sweden. The partnership aims to leverage the combined expertise of Thermo Fisher and AstraZeneca to drive innovation and strengthen the life science ecosystem. A dedicated team from Thermo Fisher will co-locate with AstraZeneca scientists to work on collaborative R&D projects with a focus initially on chromatography, molecular genomics and proteomics...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: Starlab Sustainability Weeks 2025 - From Symbolism to the Reality of a Circular Economy
articles.description: Following the successful launch of the first TipOne® racks made with TipOne recycled plastic in July, Starlab International is continuing its sustainability mission with determination: the seventh Sustainability Weeks are entirely dedicated to the circular economy. From 6 to 17 October 2025, Starlab staff will once again visit laboratories across Europe to inform about sustainable laboratory practices – this time with a particular focus on recycling systems in the lab...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.author: Katrina Miller
articles.title: Nobel Prizes This Year Offer Three Cheers for Slow Science
articles.description: The scientific Nobels announced this week — in Physiology or Medicine, Physics and Chemistry — honored achievements rooted in fundamental research from decades ago.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Interstellar Object 3I/ATLAS May Be A 10-Billion-Year-Old Time Capsule From An Earlier Age Of The Universe - IFLScience
articles.description: Interstellar Object 3I/ATLAS May Be A 10-Billion-Year-Old Time Capsule From An Earlier Age Of The Universe  IFLScienceESA’s ExoMars and Mars Express observe comet 3I/ATLAS  European Space AgencyComet 3I/ATLAS is losing water 'like a fire hose' on full blast, 'rewriting what we thought we knew' about alien star systems  Live ScienceAstronomers catch rare glimpse of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS as it flies by Mars  ABC News - Breaking News, Latest News and VideosAn Interstellar Comet Flew Past Mars, and Spacecraft Took Pictures  The New York...
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.title: Bay scallops surge on Virginia's Eastern Shore
articles.description: Virginia's bay scallop population is experiencing an unprecedented resurgence, thanks to years of dedicated restoration work led by the Batten School & VIMS Eastern Shore Laboratory (ESL) in Wachapreague. Once locally extinct due to habitat loss, bay scallops are now multiplying exponentially in the restored eelgrass meadows of the Eastern Shore's southern coastal bays, possibly setting the stage for a future recreational fishery.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How family size shapes education spending
articles.description: A new Journal of Marketing study sheds light on how family size drives differences in education spending. Conducted by researchers Phyllis Xue Wang (Renmin University of China), Ce Liang (City University of Hong Kong), and Qiyuan Wang (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), the study explores how parenting goals and perfectionism shape preferences for deficit- versus strength-based education products.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: SpaceX targets nighttime launch of competitor Amazon's satellites
articles.description: SpaceX is set to finish up its third of three contracted launches of competitor Amazon's Project Kuiper satellites on Thursday night.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Sped-up evolution may help bacteria take hold in gut microbiome
articles.description: Everywhere you go, you carry a population of microbes in your gastrointestinal tract that outnumber the human cells making up your body.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Who you talk to influences how you talk, researcher finds
articles.description: "In a sense, you listen to every person with different ears, because everyone speaks differently," says Orhun Uluşahin, who will defend his dissertation at Radboud University on October 17. His research shows that our brains adapt rapidly to a speaker in order to understand them, and that we even adapt our own speech to the person we are talking to.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Investigating genetic structure and predicted habitat expansion of endemic tree species in Southeast Asia
articles.description: Researchers at University of Tsukuba have investigated the genetic diversity and future distribution of Shorea macrophylla (Dipterocarpaceae), an important tree species endemic to Borneo. They found that populations in northeastern Borneo represent the species' origin. Climate change projections suggest that suitable habitat for this tree will expand in the future.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Hydropower dams face uncertain future as climate change drives sedimentation and glacier disappearance
articles.description: An EPFL engineer has illustrated some of the complex ways in which climate change will affect hydropower facilities, taking the Gries dam in Valais Canton as a case study.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: These ‘ghost flowers’ thrive without photosynthesis. One scientist is learning how
articles.description: Japanese botanist Kenji Suetsugu studies plants that steal carbon and nutrients from soil fungi David Malakoff 12:43 PM :heavy_check_mark:
articles.source: Science | Aaas

articles.title: Individual electrons trapped and controlled above 1 K, easing cooling limits for quantum computing
articles.description: Researchers from EeroQ, the quantum computing company pioneering electron-on-helium technology, have published a paper, titled "Sensing and Control of Single Trapped Electrons Above 1 Kelvin," in Physical Review X that details a significant milestone: the first demonstration of controlling and detecting individual electrons trapped on superfluid helium at temperatures above 1 Kelvin. This work was achieved using on-chip superconducting microwave circuits, a method compatible with existing quantum hardware.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Q&A: The 'undertaker' cells of taste, one of our least understood senses
articles.description: The next time you crave a sweet treat, go ahead and buy a bag of jellybeans—guilt free. Your indulgence will be in the interest of science.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Naked mole rats' DNA could hold key to long life
articles.description: The bald, subterranean rats are the world's longest-lived rodent.
articles.source: BBC News - Science & Environment

articles.author: Douglas Main
articles.title: Bats Catch Migratory Birds and Eat Them in Midair
articles.description: For the first time, scientists documented direct evidence of a bat preying on a bird at high altitude.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Quantum fluctuations found hidden beneath classical optical signals in polaritons
articles.description: When optical materials (molecules or solid-state semiconductors) are embedded in tiny photonic boxes, known as optical microcavities, they form hybrid light-matter states known as polaritons. Most of the optical properties of polaritons under weak illumination can be understood using textbook classical optics. Now researchers from UC San Diego show that this is not the entire story: there are quantum fluctuations lurking underneath the classical signal and they reveal a great deal about the molecules in question.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Storms are changing. Should hurricane scale change too?
articles.description: As climate change continues to reshape the intensity and behavior of hurricanes, meteorologists and researchers are examining whether the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, a decades-old classification system, still adequately communicates the full scope of hurricane hazards. While the scale remains a widely recognized tool, experts like Zachary Handlos, director of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences at Georgia Tech, suggest that a complementary system could enhance public understanding of the broader risks hurricanes pose.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Astronomers detect lowest mass dark object ever measured using gravitational lensing
articles.description: Dark matter is an enigmatic form of matter not expected to emit light, yet it is essential to understanding how the rich tapestry of stars and galaxies we see in the night sky evolved. As a fundamental building block of the universe, a key question for astronomers is whether dark matter is smooth or clumpy, as this could reveal what it is made of. Since dark matter cannot be observed directly, its properties can only be determined by observing the gravitational lensing effect, whereby the light from a more distant object is distorted and deflected by the gravity of the dark object.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Patrick Pester
articles.title: Comet 3I/ATLAS is losing water 'like a fire hose' on full blast, 'rewriting what we thought we knew' about alien star systems
articles.description: Researchers have discovered that interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS has been shedding water, providing insights into the building blocks of life outside of our solar system and the evolution of interstellar comets.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: Climate change may increase the spread of neurotoxin in the oceans
articles.description: Climate-driven oxygen loss in the Black Sea thousands of years ago triggered the expansion of microorganisms capable of producing the potent neurotoxin methylmercury. That is shown in a new study published in Nature Water, led by Eric Capo at Umeå University, which suggests that similar processes could occur in today's warming oceans.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Mathematical models reveal a 'hidden order' in dryland vegetation worldwide
articles.description: If you've ever traveled through drylands, you may have noticed striking vegetation patterns—stripes, spots, or rings—scattered across otherwise barren landscapes. From "tiger bush" in West Africa to the enigmatic "fairy circles" of Namibia, these patterns have long inspired wonder and scientific curiosity.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: From toilet cleaners to tail-tugging—new study reveals complex social behaviors of naked mole-rats
articles.description: Naked mole-rats are one of the rare examples of eusocial mammals. Eusocial animal species are those in which a single female within the group is tasked with reproduction, along with a select group of males, while the rest of the group focuses on other tasks related to maintaining the living area, gathering food, or caring for young. This kind of caste system is most often seen in insects, like ants and bees.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Absorptive roots drive forest soil carbon accumulation through iterative effects, study finds
articles.description: Since the 1980s, scientists have known fine roots (< 2 mm) are critical to ecosystem carbon cycling, with research long suggesting their contribution to soil carbon accrual may exceed that of aboveground plant parts like leaves. Yet more than 40 years later, a key knowledge gap remains: the role of multi-decadal root iterative dynamics (growth, turnover, decomposition) in soil carbon accumulation—especially for "absorptive roots," the finest, most metabolically active roots (typically the distal 2–3 root orders or < 0.5 mm in diameter).
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Ultra-sensitive light-based sensor developed for handheld Alzheimer's blood test
articles.description: Researchers have made a significant advance in the development of a blood test for Alzheimer's, creating a new sensor design that is ultra-sensitive, outperforms competing technologies and can be built into a handheld device.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: A step toward AI modeling of the whole Earth system
articles.description: Modelers have demonstrated that artificial intelligence (AI) models can produce climate simulations with more efficiency than physics-based models. However, many AI models are trained on past climate data, making it difficult for them to predict how climate might respond to future changes, such as further increases in the concentration of greenhouse gases.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Toxoplasmosis: How the pathogen exploits its own cell envelope
articles.description: According to estimates, about a third of the world's population is infected with the single-celled parasite Toxoplasma gondii, the pathogen of toxoplasmosis. Although harmless for most people, the infection can be dangerous for unborn children and people with weakened immune systems. In these cases, the pathogen can propagate rapidly and destroy infected tissue. It obtains the energy it needs for propagation by tapping the host cell and using its resources.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Where fish feed ingredients come from key for sustainability, new study finds
articles.description: A new study led by researchers from the University of Tasmania, in collaboration with international partners including The University of Manchester, has found that the environmental footprint of aquaculture feeds is influenced more by where ingredients are sourced than by the types of ingredients used.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Q&A: Exploring metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with chemist
articles.description: This year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to three researchers, including University at Albany alum Omar Yaghi, for their work on developing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)—versatile molecular materials that can be used to harvest water from desert air, capture carbon dioxide, store toxic gases and even catalyze chemical reactions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: 'Polite racism' is the subtle form of racial exclusion. Here's how to move beyond it
articles.description: In Canadian society, the narrative of multiculturalism can lean toward a "color-blind" ideology—a comforting idea that race doesn't matter and everyone is treated the same—even though such narratives mask persistent inequalities. They may also undermine efforts to address structural racism.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Research suggests rich people tend to be more selfish, but why is that?
articles.description: From Disney's Scrooge McDuck and Cruella de Vil to DC Comics' Lex Luthor and Mr. Burns in the Simpsons, there are plenty of examples of wealthy people using their money and power in evil ways. But is there any truth to the stereotype that rich people are mean?
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Plant functional diversity varies greatly with seasonal cycles and wet-dry periods, satellite images reveal
articles.description: Plant functional diversity is highly dynamic over time and fluctuates considerably. It is influenced by seasonal cycles and wet-dry periods, and varies depending on the region. These are the findings of researchers from Leipzig University, the University of Freiburg, and Aarhus University in Denmark.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Life through lens: How photos unlock stories behind places
articles.description: Research from The University of Manchester has uncovered how something as simple as walking and taking photographs can reveal powerful stories about people's lives and the places they live.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: More people believe in conspiracy theories than you might think
articles.description: Put on your tinfoil hats: New research finds that belief in conspiracy theories might be more common in the U.S. than you might think.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Proactive teams still need leadership and focus, study finds
articles.description: Having proactive people with lots of ideas isn't enough to ensure a team's success: Without focus and leadership, their efforts can fizzle out or even create friction, according to a new study from Virginia Commonwealth University.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: A hidden “backup heater” that helps burn fat and boost metabolism
articles.description: Scientists have uncovered a surprising new way the body can burn energy and stay warm. Deep inside fat tissue, they found a hidden system that helps the body use up calories, even without exercise. By studying mice, researchers discovered that brown fat — the type that keeps us warm — has a backup “heater” that kicks in when needed.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.title: Longstanding 'ice giant' classification of Uranus and Neptune might be conflicted
articles.description: What if our understanding of Uranus and Neptune's compositions have been wrong, specifically regarding their classifications as "ice giants?" This is what a recent study accepted for publication in Astronomy & Astrophysics hopes to address as a team of researchers from the University of Zurich investigated the interior structures of Uranus and Neptune.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How AI hype is reshaping journalism in five powerful ways
articles.description: The hype surrounding artificial intelligence is more than just superficial excitement—it is reorganizing how journalism operates, from newsroom priorities to public perceptions of the news, according to a new article in Digital Journalism co-authored by a University of Massachusetts Amherst journalism scholar.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Eyes in the sky: Making Earth observation data work for people
articles.description: Smarter decisions about real-world problems start with better data—and Earth observation can provide just that, thanks to European efforts to open up access to massive amounts of satellite data collected every day.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Ivan Penn and Tracey Tully
articles.title: In N.J. Governor’s Race, Energy Costs Have Become a Central Issue
articles.description: Energy costs have become a central issue in the governor’s race between Jack Ciattarelli, the Republican, and Representative Mikie Sherrill, the Democrat.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: International study reveals the current state of wine tourism worldwide
articles.description: The newly published "Global Wine Tourism Report 2025" marks a milestone for the global wine and tourism industries. With contributions from 1,310 wineries in 47 countries, it is the most comprehensive international analysis of wine tourism to date, reflecting the sector's realities and future directions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Bridging the gap: How AI can help—or hinder—the Sustainable Development Goals
articles.description: The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2015 to address some of the world's most pressing problems. The 17 goals include 169 targets such as eradicating poverty, reducing inequality and acting on climate, in service of peace, prosperity and environmental sustainability.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Broken news: Expert says supply chain thinking could help restore trust in media
articles.description: Is the news media broken? According to a survey released last October by Gallup, Americans continue to register record-low trust in the mass media—with less than one-third expressing trust in the media to report the news "fully, accurately and fairly."
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Superconductivity distorts crystal lattice of topological quantum materials
articles.description: Superconductors (materials that conduct electricity without resistance) have fascinated physicists for more than a century. While conventional superconductors are well understood, a new class of materials known as topological superconductors has attracted intense interest in recent years.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Forecasting system shows deaths in heat waves are predictable
articles.description: High temperatures can cause serious health problems and even death, especially among elderly people and people with underlying diseases. The extremely hot summers of 2022 and 2023 are estimated to have caused 60,000 and 50,000 heat-related deaths in Europe respectively. To protect people, more reliable forecasts and effective warning systems are needed.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Top conservation group meets in UAE on growing threats to nature
articles.description: The world's top conservation body kicked off its world congress Thursday in the Emirati capital Abu Dhabi, where it will unveil its updated "red list" of threatened species a day later.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How a protein complex in plant chloroplasts regulates adaptations to drought
articles.description: A heretofore unknown molecular mechanism helps plants save water in extreme drought and intense sunlight. A research team at Heidelberg University's Center for Organismal Studies (COS), in cooperation with partners at Nanjing Agricultural University (China), has discovered that a protein complex—the cysteine synthase complex—serves as a sensor in the chloroplasts. It receives and forwards stress signals and ensures that the hormone abscisic acid is formed via biosynthesis. This hormone triggers the closure of tiny pores on the leaves, thus preventing water loss.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Interpretable deep learning network significantly improves tropical cyclone intensity forecast accuracy
articles.description: Predicting tropical cyclones (TCs) accurately is crucial for disaster mitigation and public safety. Although the forecasting accuracy of TC tracks has improved substantially in recent decades, progress in the forecasting of TC intensity remains limited. In recent years, deep learning methods have shown great potential in TC intensity prediction; however, they still face challenges, including limited interpretability, cumbersome feature engineering, and unreliable real-time operational forecasts.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: World's most sensitive table-top experiment sets new limits on very high-frequency gravitational waves
articles.description: The world's most sensitive table-top interferometric system—a miniature version of miles-long gravitational-wave detectors like LIGO—has completed its first science run.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Discovery of binary stars the first step in creating 'movie of the universe'
articles.description: A discovery of binary stars could be the first step in building a more complete picture of how our galaxy formed, according to astronomers from The Australian National University (ANU). The discovery is part of an ambitious 10-year program to scan the entire southern sky every few nights.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Completed Plato spacecraft is ready for final tests
articles.description: By fitting its sunshield and solar panels, engineers have completed the construction of Plato, the European Space Agency's mission to discover Earth-like exoplanets. Plato is on track for the final key tests to confirm that it is fit for launch.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Five youths using tech to drive change win UN-backed prize
articles.description: An Indian teenager behind mobile tools to monitor water quality won a United Nations-backed youth activist prize on Thursday, alongside other young people lauded for using technology to drive positive change.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: La Nina is back, but it's weak and may be brief. Will it still amp up the Atlantic hurricane season?
articles.description: La Niña, the cooler and at times costlier flip side of El Niño, has arrived to warp weather worldwide, meteorologists said Thursday. This natural weather phenomenon often turbocharges the Atlantic hurricane season, but this La Niña may be too weak and fleeting to cause much trouble.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Earth's oxygen boom: How nickel and urea in early oceans shaped microbial life and set the stage
articles.description: The appearance of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere was a turning point in the history of our planet, forever transforming the environment and setting the stage for complex life. This event, known as the Great Oxidation Event (GOE), occurred roughly 2.1 to 2.4 billion years ago.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Image of two black holes circling each other captured for the first time
articles.description: For the first time, astronomers have managed to capture a radio image showing two black holes orbiting each other. The observation confirmed the existence of black hole pairs. In the past, astronomers have only managed to image individual black holes.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: We tracked 72,000 NSW public school students over a decade and found 19% had been suspended or expelled
articles.description: Suspending or expelling a student is the most serious disciplinary measure available to schools.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Streamlining the consciousness debate, from trees to hermit crabs
articles.description: Beyond spirited dinner party debate, establishing which creatures have consciousness matters in terms of animal welfare and conservation policy. A Michigan State University philosophy scholar has added clarity to a messy philosophical debate.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Metal-organic frameworks: Nobel-winning, tiny 'sponge crystals' with an astonishing amount of inner space
articles.description: The 2025 Nobel Prize in chemistry was awarded to Richard Robson, Susumu Kitagawa and Omar Yaghi on Oct. 8, 2025, for the development of metal-organic frameworks, or MOFs, which are tunable crystal structures with extremely high porosity. These are a class of materials that have truly changed the way scientists design and think about matter, inspiring progress in various applications.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Calm deer learn faster: How insights into individual temperament can help handlers perform health checks
articles.description: Training animals in captivity is extraordinarily challenging due to a host of factors such as an animal's natural temperament and prior negative experiences with humans. But it is often essential in places like zoos and conservation centers because animals need routine checkups and veterinary care. In a study of 12 red brocket deer (Mazama americana) in Brazil, scientists found that calm deer were much easier to train for medical procedures than restless or agitated deer.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Nobel Prize in physics awarded for ultracold electronics research that launched a quantum technology
articles.description: Quantum mechanics describes the weird behavior of microscopic particles. Using quantum systems to perform computation promises to allow researchers to solve problems in areas from chemistry to cryptography that have so many possible solutions that they are beyond the capabilities of even the most powerful nonquantum computers possible.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: NZ's native lizards are at risk from land development—future policy must ensure better protection
articles.description: New Zealand's land animals are not well protected when land is developed for new uses. Recent and proposed policy changes risk putting many species at further risk, and native lizards are particularly vulnerable.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How voice training can help teachers improve well-being in the classroom
articles.description: Teachers use their voices in the classroom to build enthusiasm, convey knowledge and defuse tensions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Driving behaviors during extreme weather events explored
articles.description: When a storm or tropical cyclone impacts mainland Australia, would you get behind the wheel of a vehicle?
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Tiny engine runs hotter than the sun to probe the frontiers of thermodynamics
articles.description: Scientists have created the world's hottest engine running at temperatures hotter than those reached in the sun's core. The team from King's College London and collaborators believe their platform could provide an unparalleled understanding of the laws of thermodynamics on a small scale, and provide the foundation for a new, efficient way to compute how proteins fold—the subject of last year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Frozen clues: Mars' crater deposits reveal a history of shrinking ice volumes through ages
articles.description: For decades, scientists have been curious about how much water Mars once had and what led to its gradual transformation into the dry planet we see today. A new study published online on September 2, 2025, in the Geology journal, sheds light on this mystery by looking deep inside Martian craters, which act like "ice archives" that store a frozen record of the planet's past. These craters reveal that Mars went through repeated ice ages over hundreds of millions of years; however, with each cycle, the amount of remaining ice decreased steadily.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: What you study in school can shape your politics, study finds
articles.description: New research led by The University of Manchester has uncovered a significant and lasting link between the subjects young people study in secondary school and their political preferences.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: An asteroid recently flew closer to Earth than the ISS
articles.description: An asteroid recently made the second closest pass to Earth ever observed on October 1st. And astronomers only found it after it had already completed its closest approach. That offers another lesson in how difficult it is to find small objects coming close to our planet in the vast dark ocean of space.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Shedding light on impact of Bank of Japan's exchange-traded fund purchase program
articles.description: It is widely recognized that the Bank of Japan's Exchange-Traded Fund (ETF) purchases had a substantial impact on stock prices. Market participants and media reports have often highlighted that the policy distorted market valuations. At the same time, they pointed out that ETF management appeared to accelerate stock lending activity as the number of ETFs held by the Bank of Japan increased over time. This pattern suggests that the stock market, particularly the lending market, has mechanisms that enhance market efficiency and counteract the effects of the Bank of Japan's policy.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Ancient DNA reveals prehistoric connections and a patrilineal society in early China
articles.description: Scientists from Peking University have uncovered new genetic evidence that sheds light on how prehistoric people in China interacted, migrated, and built their communities. Led by Professors Huang Yanyi and Pang Yuhong from the Biomedical Pioneering Innovation Center (BIOPIC), the research reveals the first direct genetic proof of a patrilineal social system in Neolithic China.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Expanded black hole collision catalog features nearly 4,000 detailed simulations
articles.description: SXS—Simulating eXtreme Spacetimes—is an ongoing scientific collaboration that has been generating simulations of dramatic events in space, particularly mergers of binary black hole systems, for several decades. Recently, SXS published a paper describing version 3 of its catalog of binary black hole simulations, six years after releasing version 2. The paper was published in the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Mobile lab finds wastewater plants produce twice as much greenhouse gas as officially estimated
articles.description: Wastewater plants emit about twice as much greenhouse gas as previously believed, according to Princeton engineers who used a mobile lab to check plants across the country.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Anna Napolitano
articles.title: Pinpointing Sewage Seeps in Hawaii
articles.description: Cesspools and septic systems, as well as coastal development, put Hawaiian coastal waters at risk of contamination.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.author: Saima May Sidik
articles.title: A Step Toward AI Modeling of the Whole Earth System
articles.description: Coupling an AI-driven model of the atmosphere with a model of the ocean could help scientists create highly efficient emulations of the entire Earth system.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.author: Bill Morris
articles.title: La salinidad del Océano Austral podría estar desencadenando la pérdida de hielo marino
articles.description: Nuevas tecnologías satelitales han revelado que el Océano Austral se está volviendo más salino, un giro inesperado de los eventos que podría representar un gran problema para la Antártida.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Secrets of the butterfly supergene that controls wing colors and patterns
articles.description: Many butterflies develop wing patterns that mimic other species to protect themselves from predators. While growing complex body parts like wings involves many genes, the difference between two versions of the same thing—like wings in different colors—is often controlled by variation in one genetic location.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Livestream sellers who act on real-time data and intuition can boost sales by 40%
articles.description: In an era dominated by algorithms and automation, new research from the University of Miami Patti and Allan Herbert Business School reveals that human intuition still holds a critical edge.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Research examines the good, bad and ugly of true crime media
articles.description: True crime is a lucrative genre, topping ratings and spawning online communities. Despite its popularity—and its ability to highlight cases that need attention—the production of true crime has a dark side, often adding to the trauma experienced by victims' loved ones.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Nanoscale X-ray imaging reveals bulk altermagnetism in MnTe
articles.description: Magnetic materials have been known since ancient times and play an important role in modern society, where the net magnetic order offers routes to energy harvesting and data processing. It is the net magnetic moment of ferromagnets that has so far been key to their applications, with an alternative type of magnetic material, the antiferromagnet, deemed "useless" by their discoverer Louis Néel in his Nobel Prize lecture.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Rooting for green: Study explores why small-city residents plant trees
articles.description: A new University of Alberta study helps get at the root of why residents—particularly in a small city—plant and maintain trees on their property.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: High-fiber white flour passes the taste test
articles.description: White bread could soon get a healthy makeover without sacrificing taste or texture, according to new research that tested experimental loaves enriched with dietary fiber.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Nature inspires researchers to help recover trillions of dollars in critical resources
articles.description: An advanced filtration system inspired by nature that can recover untapped critical resources such as copper and lithium from mining waste is being developed by scientists from The Australian National University (ANU) in collaboration with Rio Tinto.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Color influences life or death food choices for seabirds foraging at sea, research reveals
articles.description: Seabirds foraging at sea face deadly threats from eating plastics and being caught up in longline fisheries bycatch, but a new study reveals their color preferences play a big part in their vulnerability to these human activities.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How nature can make urban dwellers healthier
articles.description: A study by Rutgers ecologist Myla Aronson and colleagues has found "overwhelming" evidence that increasing biodiversity in cities—establishing parks, installing native plants and encouraging sustainable landscaping—can significantly improve human health.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Kimberley Lane
articles.title: Prime Day deals extended: There's still a chance to save on cameras, binoculars and telescopes
articles.description: These deals are still live after Prime Day, but we don't know how long for. This is your last chance to save on the best binoculars, cameras and telescopes before Black Friday.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.author: Nathan Gock
articles.title: Poor sleep can cause illness
articles.description: New research examining sleep data suggests poor sleep in terms of length, depth, and waking in the night is associated with illnesses like Parkinson’s disease and type 2 diabetes.The post Poor sleep can cause illness appeared first on Sciworthy.
articles.source: Science For Everyone: The Latest Research Papers Explained

articles.title: Simulations unveil the electrodynamic nature of black hole mergers and other spacetime collisions
articles.description: Gravitational waves are energy-carrying waves produced by the acceleration or disturbance of massive objects. These waves, which were first directly observed in 2015, are known to be produced during various cosmological phenomena, including mergers between two black holes that orbit each other (i.e., binary black holes).
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Lisa Grossman
articles.title: The Vera Rubin Observatory is set to revolutionize astronomy
articles.description: Equipped with the world’s largest digital camera, this new telescope is poised to help solve some of the universe’s biggest mysteries.
articles.source: Science News For Students

articles.title: Recent advancements in algae technology - Biofuels International
articles.description: Recent advancements in algae technology  Biofuels International
articles.source: Google News Science IN

articles.title: Wheat varieties bred for top yields in good conditions also excel in tough environments
articles.description: José Luis Araus, professor at the University of Barcelona's Faculty of Biology and member of Agrotecnio—CERCA center in agrotechnology—participated in a study showing that wheat varieties that perform best under ideal conditions (water, nutrients, temperature) also yield more in challenging environmental and agronomic situations, such as excessive heat or drought.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Top nature group to unveil new 'red list' of threatened species
articles.description: The world's top conservation body is holding its world congress starting Thursday in the Emirati capital Abu Dhabi and will unveil its updated "red list" of threatened species.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Hairy Frog: The Wolverine Frog That Breaks Its Bones To Make Claws When Threatened - IFLScience
articles.description: Hairy Frog: The Wolverine Frog That Breaks Its Bones To Make Claws When Threatened  IFLScience
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.author: Olivia Lutz
articles.title: NIH Student Grant Cancellation Will Weaken Scientific Innovation
articles.description: Earlier this year, the National Institutes of Health abruptly terminated fellowships awarded to graduate students under a funding mechanism designed to increase diversity. One student whose grant was pulled argues that cutting support for research training will weaken scientific innovation in the U.S.
articles.source: Truth Beauty Science. - Undark

articles.author: Dave Petley
articles.title: The report of the Board of Inquiry into the 14 January 2025 McCrae Landslide
articles.description: The tribunal has concluded that a major leak in a water main, which released 40 million liters of water, triggered the failure On 14 January 2025, the McCrae landslide occurred on the Mornington Peninsula in Australia. The site is located at [-38.34631, 144.93500]. I posted about this event at the time, noting that local residents had […]
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Prior Scientific introduces the HF108B High Speed Filter Wheel
articles.description: Prior Scientific is pleased to introduce the HF108B high-speed filter wheel, engineered to provide fast and reliable optical switching for demanding imaging applications. Designed to accommodate up to eight 32 mm filters, the HF108B allows users to easily configure illumination to meet specific requirements. Well-suited for high-speed widefield fluorescence microscopy and integration into confocal or super-resolution instruments, the HF108B features...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: AI model forecasts disease risk decades in advance
articles.description: Imagine a future where your medical history could help predict what health conditions you might face in the next two decades. Researchers have developed a generative AI model that uses large-scale health records to estimate how human health may change over time. It can forecast the risk and timing of over 1,000 diseases and predict health outcomes over a decade in advance...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: Scientists suggest the brain may work best with 7 senses, not just 5
articles.description: Scientists at Skoltech developed a new mathematical model of memory that explores how information is encoded and stored. Their analysis suggests that memory works best in a seven-dimensional conceptual space — equivalent to having seven senses. The finding implies that both humans and AI might benefit from broader sensory inputs to optimize learning and recall.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.title: Planet Y? Astronomers find fresh clues of hidden world in our solar system - daily-sun.com
articles.description: Planet Y? Astronomers find fresh clues of hidden world in our solar system  daily-sun.comSolar System Might Have A Hidden 'Planet Y'. What We Know  NDTVAstronomers reveal evidence for a hidden 'Planet Y' beyond Neptune  MoneycontrolScientists suggest possibility of new planet in solar system  Patrika News40 years on, it’s confirmed — NASA finds a long-masked object inside the Solar System  ecoportal.net
articles.source: Google News Science IN

articles.author: Brian Wang
articles.title: TESLA All Time Highs by Nov 7, 2025, Revolutionary Unboxed Manufacturing, NVIDIA’s Huge AI Bets
articles.description: Tesla’s overnight and daytime price swings around $425-450 and the day ended at $436. The sell-off was due to disappointment over the new affordable Model 3 and Y not being as revolutionary or cheap as some hoped. Expecting a strong Q3 earnings call on October 22, EPS beats (65–75¢ vs. analyst 39–59¢ estimates) . Energy ... Read more
articles.source: Next Big Future

articles.author: Carl Zimmer
articles.title: She Studied How Foresting Affects Pollinators
articles.description: Kim Ballare was a research ecologist with the U.S. Forest Service until her federal grant “got snatched away.”
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.title: She Found a Link Between Air Pollution and Infertility
articles.description: Shruthi Mahalingaiah, a Harvard researcher, investigated the fertility risks women face from air pollution. But her grant was canceled.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.title: He Studied How Emissions Are Heating Up U.S. Cities
articles.description: “Fundamentally, we were trying to learn about these systems to prevent people from dying unnecessarily from heat,” said Kevin Gurney, an atmospheric scientist.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Alan Burdick
articles.title: Has Your Scientific Work Been Cut? We Want to Hear.
articles.description: For a new series, Times journalists are speaking with scientists whose research has ended as a result of policy changes by the Trump administration.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Brian Wang
articles.title: Top AI Models Get $60 Billion Invested in a 3 Month Period
articles.description: Total funding for the top 10 AI companies is ~$115B and 70% is in 2025. Enterprise shift (Cohere/Inflection) yields 2-3x faster ROI than consumer bets. The AI funding does not include the $60-80 billion per year that Google speeds on AI capex. ROI signals are strong—enterprise AI ARR grew 300% YoY.
articles.source: Next Big Future

articles.title: Antarctic Ocean of the last ice age reveals how a critical process of CO₂ storage may slow again
articles.description: Off the coast of Antarctica, the sea ice retreated toward the southernmost continent and, like a bottle cap taken off a soda bottle, that reduced pressure slowed down a process of critical carbon dioxide capture, dramatically accelerating the warming of the planet.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Introduced animals change how island plants spread, global study finds
articles.description: On islands, many plants rely on animals such as birds, bats and reptiles to disperse their seeds and help them grow in new places. When native animals go extinct, this naturally reduces seed dispersal.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Australia–Papua New Guinea defense treaty: What we can learn from history to make this new alliance work
articles.description: After a slight delay, Australia and Papua New Guinea formally signed a defense treaty this week committing the two nations to come to each other's aid if one is faced with an attack.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Protein sidekick exhibits dual roles in stress granule assembly and disassembly
articles.description: Stress granules are droplet-like protein hubs that temporarily shield fragile RNA from cellular stresses such as toxins. VCP is a protein essential for breaking up stress granules and has been linked to neurodegenerative diseases. However, VCP has a protein partner, ASPL, whose role has been unclear until now.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: AI tool helps match enzymes to substrates
articles.description: A new artificial intelligence-powered tool can help researchers determine how well an enzyme fits with a desired target, helping them find the best enzyme and substrate combination for applications from catalysis to medicine to manufacturing.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Chinese medicine extract tetrandrine's precise mechanism of action opens new avenues for drug discovery
articles.description: A research team led by Prof. Ben Ko Chi-bun, Associate Professor of the PolyU Department of Applied Biology and Chemical Technology, has discovered the critical mechanism of action of tetrandrine, a compound derived from Chinese medicine Stephania tetrandra. Their work opens the door to innovative treatments for viral infections and neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Carbon monitoring: Modeling effort helps to quickly and accurately estimate forest biomass
articles.description: A tree can sequester quite a bit of carbon, and forests can sequester and store quite a bit more, but knowing exactly how much is important for many reasons, from planning and management decisions to assessing a forest's health. However, estimating how much carbon is stored in a forested landscape is a tedious and time-consuming process.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Scientists discover regulatory pathway behind cyanobacteria's carbon-fixing factories
articles.description: Long before plants and algae, cyanobacteria were already performing photosynthesis—filling Earth's skies with oxygen and setting the stage for life as we know it. The ultra-prevalent bacteria are critical to the global carbon cycle, responsible for fixing as much as 30% of the world's carbon dioxide and converting it into oxygen we breathe. And because they're the simplest organisms that carry out this complex process, they're both ideal for studying fundamentals of biology as well as promising contenders for bioengineering.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: 'Solids full of holes': Nobel-winning materials explained
articles.description: The chemistry Nobel was awarded on Wednesday to three scientists who discovered a revolutionary way of making materials full of tiny holes that can do everything from sucking water out of the desert air to capturing climate-warming carbon dioxide.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Trump's $100,000 H-1B visa fee threatens rural schools and hospitals reliant on immigrant workers
articles.description: When Rob Coverdale started his job in 2023 as superintendent of the K-12 Crow Creek Tribal School in South Dakota, there were 15 unfilled teaching positions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Your phone rings, and it's a number from Sweden. Do you answer? A Nobel Prize winner didn't
articles.description: For some Nobel Prize winners this year, the news came with a knock at the door before dawn. For others, it was a long-awaited phone call honoring a discovery made decades ago.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Farmed totoaba could curb poaching
articles.description: The trade of totoaba has all the intrigue of a crime thriller. Dollars and drugs change hands as a criminal cartel vies against the government. Communities and endangered species are caught in the crosshairs of a lucrative illicit trade. It may then come as a surprise that the totoaba is a fish.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: What work means to working-class young men in an age of increasing automation
articles.description: For years we've been warned that technological advances and artificial intelligence (AI) are set to sweep people out of work. But when we think about whose jobs are really under threat, the answer isn't quite so simple.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How household composition influences food behaviors and spending
articles.description: New data sheds light on consumer perceptions of farms and firms in the food supply chain and provides an update on the sustainability of American diets, according to the September Consumer Food Insights Report (CFI).
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Opinion: Why US military action against Latin America's cartels won't win the war on drugs
articles.description: At the start of September 2025, US president Donald Trump sent a naval task force into the Caribbean to tackle drug trafficking in the region. The initiative has led to strikes on four alleged drug boats off the Venezuelan coast so far, killing at least 21 people.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Emily Gardner
articles.title: Sharpiegate Scientist Takes the Helm at NOAA
articles.description: Meteorologist and atmospheric scientist Neil Jacobs was confirmed as the new leader of NOAA on Tuesday evening.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Understanding the climate cost of cleaning our water
articles.description: Each year, U.S. wastewater treatment plants clean trillions of gallons of water, from what we flush down the toilet to drain down the sink.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Enhancing the industrial relevance of alcohol dehydrogenase enzymes by exploiting their 'hidden reactivity'
articles.description: Amides and thioesters are ubiquitous compounds in chemistry, used for the production of medicines, natural products, and advanced materials. Traditionally, their synthesis is a messy business, involving wasteful reagents, toxic metals, or energy-intensive conditions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer
articles.title: Trump’s Energy Cuts Punished Mostly Blue States. Red States Might Be Next.
articles.description: As New York and other states tally the damage, a leaked document suggests more Energy Department cuts may be coming.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Mars dust devils mapped in detail, revealing faster winds than expected
articles.description: Combing through 20 years of images from the European Space Agency's Mars Express and ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter spacecraft, scientists have tracked 1,039 tornado-like whirlwinds to reveal how dust is lifted into the air and swept around Mars's surface.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: 1,000-year-old gut microbiome revealed for young man who lived in pre-Hispanic Mexico
articles.description: Analysis of preserved feces and intestinal tissue has revealed specific types of bacteria that were present in the microbiome of a young adult man who lived in Mexico about 1,000 years ago, prior to Spanish colonization. Santiago Rosas-Plaza of Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México and colleagues present these findings in PLOS One.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Composing crews for Mars missions: Team diversity may foster resilience
articles.description: Simulation results highlight how team composition shapes stress, health, performance, and cohesion in long-duration space missions, according to a study published October 8, 2025, in the open-access journal PLOS One by Iser Pena and Hao Chen of the Stevens Institute of Technology, U.S. In particular, team diversity in personality traits may contribute to greater resilience under extended isolation and operational load.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Nobel chemistry prize awarded for crystal materials that could revolutionize green technology
articles.description: Three scientists have been awarded the 2025 Nobel prize in chemistry for discovering a new form of molecular architecture: crystals that contain large cavities.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How different bird species forage together in the Antarctic
articles.description: It's a scene fit for a nature documentary: In the frigid ocean surrounding Antarctica, the water boils over as seabirds dive from above and marine animals like seals and whales rise from the depths to all feast on krill.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: The alleged British links to mass deforestation and displacement in a conflict few have even heard of
articles.description: UK banks, energy giants and arms exporters are at the heart of one of the world's least-known human rights and environmental crises, our research has revealed.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Domestic violence impacts nearly two-thirds of Californians, survey finds
articles.description: Nearly two-thirds of Californians (63%) say they are affected by domestic violence, either directly or indirectly through a family member or friend and nearly one-third (31%) identify as survivors, according to new statewide survey commissioned by Blue Shield of California Foundation.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Bacterial 'bubbles' hitchhike to reach the cell surface, researchers discover
articles.description: Researchers at Umeå University have discovered that the microscopic "bubbles" released by bacteria in our body do not just drift around randomly. Instead, they use the thin protrusions of cells as a transport route to quickly and efficiently reach their target with their contents.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Open source mega-constellations could solve overcrowding
articles.description: Duplicating expensive resources is expensive and wasteful, and most people would agree it's unnecessary. However, the planned increase in major satellite constellations is currently causing a massive duplication of resources as individual companies and even countries try to set up their own infrastructure in space.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
